root.WPSH01:
Connect to wireless network Help

WPS stands for Wi-Fi Protected Setup. This is a process that let you connect to the wireless network easily, and you don't have to specificly configure the wireless settings like SSID, security mode, and passphrase.
root.WPSH02: You can connect to wireless AP either through the "Push 'N' Connect" or "PIN Number".
root.WPSH03: With the "Push 'N' Connect" method, you have to complete the process by clicking a button on the wireless AP/router (either a hardware button or a software button on the AP's GUI).
root.WPSH04: With the "PIN Number" method, you have to write down the client's PIN and enter it in the AP's WPS PIN GUI. You have to start the AP WPS process at the same time after you finish to enter PIN in AP's GUI, and you must also click Next to start WPS here.
root.SWS045: Note: The passphrase is case sensitive. "Netgear" is not the same as "netgear".
root.SWS054: Detecting the wireless network in your neighborhood. This typically takes 10 seconds.
root.SWSW01: WARNING: Selecting the incorrect region may result in a violation of applicable law. Do you agree to act in accordance with these settings?
root.SWSW02: “This security type WPA-PSK [AES] or WPA2-PSK [TKIP] is not supported.”
root.SWSW04: WPA-PSK [TKIP] ONLY operates at "Up to 54Mbps" (legacy G) mode, not N mode.
root.SWSW05: NETGEAR recommends that you use WPA2-PSK [AES] to get full N rate support.
root.SWSE01: Character is not allowed in passphrase.
root.SWSE02: Character is not allowed in SSID.
root.SWSE04: The passphrase is too long. The maximum length is 63 characters.
root.SWSE05: Insufficient passphrase length. It should be a minimum of 8 characters long.
root.SWSE09: Keys length should be 26 Hex (0~9 and A~F) chars.
root.SWSE10: Keys length should be 10 Hex (0~9 and A~F) chars.
root.SWSH01:
Wireless Help

NOTE: To ensure proper agency compliance and compatibility between similar products in your area, the operating region must be set correctly.

Placement of the Router to Optimize Wireless Connectivity

The operating distance or range of your wireless connection can vary significantly based on the physical placement of the router. For best results, place your router:

  • Near the center of the area in which your PCs will operate.
  • In an elevated location such as a high shelf.
  • Away from potential sources of interference, such as PCs, microwave ovens, and cordless phones.
  • Away from large metal surfaces.

Note: Failure to follow these guidelines can result in significant performance degradation or inability to wirelessly connect to the router.
root.SWSH02:
Wireless Network

Name (SSID)

Enter a value of up to 32 alphanumeric characters. The same name (SSID) must be assigned to all wireless devices in your network. The default SSID is NETGEAR, but NETGEAR strongly recommends that you change your network's name (SSID) to a different value. This value is case-sensitive. For example, NETGEAR is not the same as NETGEAr.

Region

Select your region from the drop-down list. This field displays the region of operation for which the wireless interface is intended. It might not be legal to operate the device in a region other than the region shown here. If your country or region is not listed, please check with your local government agency or check the NETGEAR website for more information about which channels to use.
root.SWSH03:
Mode

Select the wireless mode you want to use. The options are:

  • Up to 54 Mbps. Legacy Mode, with a maximum speed of up to 54 Mbps for b/g networks.
  • Up to 145 Mbps. Neighbor-Friendly Mode, with a speed of up to 145 Mbps in the presence of neighboring wireless networks.
  • Up to 300 Mbps. Performance Mode, with a maximum Wireless-N speed of up to 300 Mbps.

The default is Up to 300 Mbps, which allows all 11b and 11g and 11n wireless stations.
root.SWSH04:
Security Options

  • None - no data encryption
  • WEP - Wired Equivalent Privacy, use WEP 64- or 128-bit data encryption
  • WPA-PSK [TKIP] - Wi-Fi Protected Access with Pre-Shared Key, use WPA-PSK standard encryption with TKIP encryption type
  • WPA2-PSK [AES] - Wi-Fi Protected Access version 2 with Pre-Shared Key, use WPA2-PSK standard encryption with the AES encryption type

To achieve the best performance with 11N wireless adapters under robust security network, NETGEAR recommends that you change your network's security option to WPA2-PSK.
root.SWSH05:
Security Encryption (WEP)

Encryption Strength

Select the WEP Encryption level:

  • 64-bit (sometimes called 40-bit) encryption
  • 128-bit encryption
root.SWSH06:
Security Encryption (WEP) Key

If WEP is enabled, you can manually or automatically program the four data encryption keys. These values must be identical on all PCs and Access Points in your network.

Automatic Key Generation (Passphrase)

Enter a word or group of printable characters in the Passphrase box and click the Generate button to automatically configure the WEP Key(s). If encryption strength is set to 64 bit, then each of the four key boxes will automatically be populated with key values. If encryption strength is set to 128 bit, then only the selected WEP key box will automatically be populated with key values.

Manual Entry Mode

Select which of the four keys will be used, and enter the matching WEP key information for your network in the selected key box.

For 64-bit WEP - Enter ten hexadecimal digits (any combination of 0-9, A-F).

For 128-bit WEP - Enter twenty-six hexadecimal digits (any combination of 0-9, A-F).

Be sure to click Apply to save your settings in this menu.
root.SWSH07:
Security Encryption (WPA-PSK)

If selected, you must use TKIP encryption, and enter the WPA passphrase (Network key). Enter a word or group of printable characters in the Passphrase box. The Passphrase must be constituted of either 8 to 63 ASCII characters or exactly 64 hex digits. A hex digit is one of the following characters:
0, 1, 2, ..., 8, 9, A, B, C, D, E, and F.

Be sure to click Apply to save your settings.
root.SWSH08:
Security Encryption (WPA2-PSK)

WPA2 is a newer version of WPA. Only select this if all the wireless clients in your network support WPA2. If selected, you must use AES encryption, and enter the WPA passphrase (Network key). Enter a word or group of printable characters in the Passphrase box. The Passphrase must be constituted of either 8 to 63 ASCII characters or exactly 64 hex digits. A hex digit is one of the following characters:
0, 1, 2, ..., 8, 9, A, B, C, D, E, and F.
root.SWSH09:
To Save Or Cancel Changes

Click Apply to have your changes take effect.
Click Cancel to return to the previous settings.

root.SIASH01:
Device's IP Address Setup Help

The IP address settings of this device.
root.SIASH02: Get Dynamically From Router: The dhcp client of device will get an IP address automatically after it connects to your existing router.
root.SIASH03: Use Static IP Address: Set static IP address and related information of your network for this device.
root.SIASH04: • IP Address: Type the IP address of your device in dotted decimal notation.
root.SIASH05: • IP Subnet Mask: The subnet mask specifies the network number portion of an IP address. The device will automatically calculate the subnet mask based on the IP address that you assign. Unless you are implementing subnetting, use 255.255.255.0 as the subnet mask (computed by the device).
root.SIASH06: • Gateway IP Address: Type the IP address of your gateway in dotted decimal notation.
root.SIASH07: • Primary DNS: Specify the primary DNS server you want to use.
root.SIASH08: • Secondary DNS: Specify the secondary DNS server you want to use.
root.SIASH09:
To Save Or Cancel Changes

Click Apply to have your changes take effect.
Click Cancel to return to the previous settings.
root.MDSH01:
Device Status Help

You can use the Device Status screen to check the current settings and statistics for your device. This screen shows you the current settings. If something needs to be changed, you will have to change it on the relevant screen.
root.MDSH02: Hardware Version: This is the hardware version of this device.
root.MDSH03: Firmware Version: This is the current software the device is using. This will change if you upgrade your device.
root.MDSH04: GUI Language Version: This is the current language version the device GUI is using. This will change if you upgrade your device.
root.MDSH05: Wireless Connection Status: These are the current wireless connection status.
root.MDSH06: • Wireless Connection - indicates the wireless conneciton is Connect or Disconnect.
root.MDSH07: <li>Link Rate (Tx/Rx) - indicates the actual transmission (Tx)and receive (Rx) link rate in the current wireless connection.
root.MDSH08: LAN Port: These are the current settings, as set in the IP Address Setup page.
root.MDSH09: <ul> <li>MAC Address - the physical address of the Device, as seen from the local LAN.
root.MDSH10: <li>IP Address - LAN IP address of the Device.
root.MDSH11: • DHCP Client - indicates either On (IP address is obtained dynamically) or Off.
root.MDSH12: <li>Subnet Mask - subnet mask associated with the LAN IP address.
root.MDSH13: <li>Default Gateway - displays the IP address of default gateway.
root.MDSH14: • DNS Server - displays the IP address of the current DNS (Domain Name Server).
root.MDSH15: Wireless Port: These are the current settings, as set in the Wireless Settings page.
root.MDSH20: • Security type - indicates the security type used in the wireless network.
root.MDSH21: Click Show Statistics to see device performance statistics such as the number of packets sent and number of packets received for each port.
root.MDSH22: Click DHCP Status to see information about your current DHCP connection.

root.MBSH01:
Backup Settings Help

This screen allows you to back up, restore, and erase the device's current settings.

Once you have the device working correctly, you should back up the information to have it available if something goes wrong. When you back up the settings, they are saved as a file on your computer. You can restore the device's settings from this file.

To create a backup file of the current settings:

  1. Click Back Up.
  2. If you do not have your browser set up to save downloaded files automatically, locate where you want to save the file, rename it if you like, and click Save.
    If you have your browser set up to save downloaded files automatically, the file is saved to the your browser's download location on the hard disk and is called
root.MBSH02:
.

IMPORTANT!Once you start restoring settings or erasing the device, do not try to go online, turn off the device, shut down the computer, or do anything else to the device until it finishes restarting! This should take only a minute or so. When the Test light stops blinking, wait a few more seconds before doing anything with the device.
root.MBSH03:
To restore settings from a backup file:

  1. Click Browse.
  2. Locate and select the previously saved backup file (by default,
root.MBSH04:
).
  • Click Restore.
    A window appears letting you know that the device has been successfully restored to the previous settings. The device will restart. This will take about 1 minute.
    IMPORTANT!Do not try to go online, turn off the device, shut down the computer, or do anything else to the device until it finishes restarting! When the Test light stops blinking, wait a few more seconds before doing anything with the device.
  • Close the message window.

    • To erase the current settings and reset the device to the original factory default settings:

    • Click Erase.
      IMPORTANT!Do not try to go online, turn off the device, shut down the computer, or do anything else to the device until the device finishes restarting! When the Test light stops blinking, wait a few more seconds before doing anything with the device.

    After you have erased the device's current settings, the device's password will be password, the LAN IP address will be 192.168.1.1
root.MSPE02: The password you typed does not match. Please enter it again.
root.MSPH01:
Set Password Help

You use the Set Password screen to change the password you use to access the Settings screens,not your ISP account password.

To change the password:

  1. Type the old password.
    The default password for the device is password.
  2. Type a new password, and type it again in the Repeat New Password field to confirm it.
    Note: Be sure to write it down in a secure location.
  3. Click Apply to change the password, or click Cancel to keep the current password.

Note: If you have backed up the device settings previously, you should do a new backup so that the settings file includes the new password.

root.MFUH01:
Firmware Upgrade Assistant Help

The device can automatically detect whether a new version of the firmware is available on the Internet.

Click Yes if you want to start the detection now.
Click No if you want do not want to check for a new version now.

If you prefer to check for a new version later, you can do this on the Firmware Upgrade screen.

If you do not want to see this message again the next time you log in, select the Do not display this message again check box, and click No.
root.MFUH02:
Firmware Upgrade Help

You install new versions of the device's software using the Firmware Upgrade page.

Go to the NETGEAR Web site to get new versions of the device software. After downloading the file, you'll need to unzip (or unstuff) it before upgrading the device.

IMPORTANT! Once you click Upload do NOT interrupt the process of sending the software to the device and restarting the device. If you think the process may be interrupted in some way, click Cancel to keep the current device software.

To upgrade device software:

  1. Go to www.NETGEAR.com and download the updated software.
  2. If not done automatically, uncompress the file.
    You may want to read the Release Notes before continuing.
  3. Click Browse.
  4. Locate and select the file you just downloaded and uncompressed.
  5. Click Upload to send the software to the device.
    This loads the new software in the device and causes the device to restart.
    Note: Do not try to go online, turn off the device, shutdown the computer or do anything else to the device until the device finishes restarting! When the Ready light stops blinking, wait a few more seconds before doing anything.
  6. Click Status and check the Firmware Version to verify that your device now has the new software installed.

IMPORTANT! In some cases, such as a major upgrades, you may need to reconfigure your device after upgrading it. Refer to the Release Notes included with the software to find out if you need to reconfigure the device.

root.AWSH01:
Advanced Wireless Help

Warning: The device is already configured with the optimum settings. Do not alter these settings unless directed by NETGEAR support. Incorrect settings might disable the device unexpectedly.

Fragmentation Threshold, CTS/RTS Threshold, Preamble Mode

These settings are reserved for wireless testing and advanced configuration only. Do not change these settings.

To Save or Cancel Changes

Click Apply to have your changes take effect.
Click Cancel to return to the previous settings.
